channel.title: BBC News - UK Politics
channel.copyright: Copyright: (C) British Broadcasting Corporation, see http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/help/rss/4498287.stm for terms and conditions of reuse.

item.title: Afghanistan: UK troops sent to get Britons out as Taliban advances
item.description: About 600 troops will be deployed on a short-term basis after the Taliban seized several cities.

item.title: Sturgeon urges UK government to reassess Cambo oil field plan
item.description: The first minister says proposals should be re-examined due to the severity of the climate emergency.

item.title: Starmer rejects McCluskey's claim Labour could be finished under his leadership
item.description: The Unite boss warns Labour could "go under" if Sir Keir Starmer remains leader, in a new autobiography.

item.title: Electric cars: Do ministers put their motor where their mouth is?
item.description: Politicians are keen for us to live greener lives, but how many have taken the electric car plunge?

item.title: Afghanistan: Ex-Tory ministers attack Biden over troops pullout
item.description: Tory politicians say it is not too late for UK troops to stay - but the government rules it out.

item.title: UK economy rebounds as Covid restrictions ease
item.description: Retail, restaurants and hotels show strong growth between April and June but data misses forecasts.

item.title: Climate: WWF warns UK spending is lagging behind targets
item.description: The conservation group WWF says the UK government must keep its promises on climate change.

item.title: UK deportation flight to Jamaica leaves with dozens reprieved
item.description: A plane to Jamaica chartered by the Home Office was carrying just seven passengers, lawyers say.

item.title: David Cameron in row over promoting genetics firm Illumina
item.description: Mr Cameron encouraged Matt Hancock to speak at a conference co-hosted by Illumina before it won a government contract.

item.title: GCSE results 2021: Record passes and top grades
item.description: Record high GCSE grades in a second year of exams disrupted by the pandemic.

item.title: UK police involved for months in embassy spy case - Met boss
item.description: A man working for the British Embassy was arrested near Berlin accused of spying for Russia.

item.title: A-levels: Warning over private and state school gap
item.description: The former school recovery tsar warns of growing educational inequality as a result of the pandemic.

item.title: Operation Brock: Brexit lorry controls 'could stay'
item.description: Lorry controls brought in for Brexit could stay - in case of any type of disruption near the border.

item.title: Gurkha veterans on hunger strike outside Downing Street
item.description: Gurkha veterans say they will starve themselves to death if they do not get pensions equal to British soldiers.

item.title: Covid: Tories accuse Starmer of hypocrisy over travel tests
item.description: He is accused of ignoring Welsh Labour ministers' insistence that travellers use higher-cost tests.

item.title: Covid-19: More than 75% of UK adults now double-jabbed
item.description: But Oxford vaccine chief Prof Sir Andrew Pollard warns Covid herd immunity is "not a possibility".

item.title: Oxford-jab chief criticises UK's Covid booster plan
item.description: Health Secretary Sajid Javid says he plans to begin the third jab rollout in a matter of weeks.

item.title: Kirsty Williams: Abuse of women in politics getting worse
item.description: Kirsty Williams says she could not keep her family safe from trolling while Welsh education minister.

item.title: David Cameron personally promoted Greensill to investors
item.description: BBC Panorama finds Mr Cameron appeared alongside the controversial company's founder at a 2019 event.

item.title: Humza Yousaf launches legal action over Dundee nursery 'discrimination'
item.description: Humza Yousaf says his daughter was twice refused a place at the nursery, which denies discrimination.

item.title: Test and Trace boss Dido Harding to step down from NHS role
item.description: Boris Johnson promised a "world-beating" system, but it was heavily criticised during her tenure.

item.title: A-level results 2021: Top grades reach record high
item.description: The second year of results after cancelled exams sees the highest level of A* and A grades at A-level.

item.title: Defibrillators: PM urged to back call for devices in all schools
item.description: Mark King, whose son died 10 years ago, says the devices should be as common fire extinguishers.

item.title: Climate change: Make coal history says PM after climate warning
item.description: Boris Johnson calls for a shift towards clean energy sources after "sobering" report on climate change.

item.title: COP26: Minister says summit must be a turning point
item.description: Zac Goldsmith says COP26 must be a "turning point", despite warnings that costs of tackling climate change will hit poor families.

item.title: Geronimo the alpaca: Who is he and why has he hit the headlines?
item.description: The life of Geronimo the alpaca is at the centre of a row between his owner and the government.

item.title: Climate change: IPCC report is 'code red for humanity'
item.description: Heating from humans has caused irreparable damage to the Earth that may get worse in coming decades.

item.title: Covid: Home-working officials won't get paid less, says minister
item.description: Business Secretary Kwasi Kwarteng said mixing home and office working was "here to stay" post-Covid.

item.title: A-level results: Students have been treated fairly - watchdog
item.description: The head of the exams regulator defends the system for deciding grades ahead of A-level and GCSE results day.

item.title: Greensill: David Cameron 'made $10m' before company’s collapse
item.description: A letter indicates the former PM received millions from shares in the controversial collapsed firm.

item.title: NHS waiting lists could rise to 14 million in England next year - report
item.description: Currently five million people are on hospital waiting lists, but there is a warning of a hidden backlog.

item.title: Geronimo the alpaca: Protesters march on Downing Street
item.description: More than 100,000 people sign a petition calling on Boris Johnson to halt the alpaca's execution.

item.title: No apology from Boris Johnson over Thatcher coal mine closures remark
item.description: But No 10 says Boris Johnson recognises the pain of closures, after he said they helped the climate.

item.title: Covid PCR costs can be excessive and exploitative, says Javid
item.description: The health secretary calls on a watchdog to investigate "exploitative" firms overcharging holidaymakers.

item.title: PM's coal mining 'joke' no laughing matter, say MPs
item.description: Boris Johnson said that closing mines had given the UK an early start fighting climate change.

item.title: Climate change: Time running out to stop catastrophe - Alok Sharma
item.description: Despite his warning, the Tory climate chief does not rule out future fossil fuel projects in the UK.

item.title: Geronimo the Alpaca must be put down to protect cows - minister
item.description: Putting animals down is soul-destroying but necessary to stop bovine TB, the environment secretary says.

item.title: Sir Keir Starmer: Labour should be proud of Tony Blair's record
item.description: Labour leader Sir Keir Starmer vows turn the party "inside out" to win the next general election.

item.title: Boris Johnson will not isolate after Covid case among staff
item.description: No 10 says he was not in close contact with a staffer who tested positive during a visit to Scotland.

item.title: Keeping old computers going costs government £2.3bn a year, says report
item.description: Just under half the entire IT budget goes on patching up outdated systems, a government report says.

item.title: Covid: Live events to be protected by £750m government-backed insurance scheme
item.description: Music festivals are among the events in the UK that will be protected if they are forced to cancel.

item.title: New oil development off Shetland should not go ahead - Starmer
item.description: The Labour leader says it would send the wrong signal for the Cambo oil field to be approved ahead of COP26.

item.title: Conservative donors have no influence on policy, insists Grant Shapps
item.description: Grant Shapps defends big donors getting access to Boris Johnson and Rishi Sunak.

item.title: Paul Embery: Pro-Brexit fire union official unfairly sacked, tribunal finds
item.description: A tribunal finds Paul Embery was subject to a "witch hunt" after appearing at a Leave Means Leave rally.

item.title: Sajid Javid says NHS waiting lists will rise
item.description: The health secretary urges people to come forward and "know that the NHS is there for them".

item.title: Exams: Keir Starmer calls for Gavin Williamson to lose job
item.description: It is "pretty astonishing" that the education secretary is still in his job, says the Labour leader.

item.title: Trolling of women in politics 'worrying'
item.description: Kirsty Williams said she had felt unable to keep her family safe from the trolling on social media.

item.title: Rishi Sunak says 'not complacent' about UK growth figures
item.description: Chancellor Rishi Sunak says there's still work to be done as the UK economy recovers from lockdown.

item.title: Yousaf warns 'Covid has not gone away' as restrictions ease
item.description: The health secretary warns that 'Covid has not gone away' ahead of Monday's significant milestone.

item.title: Berlin embassy arrest: A case of old-school spying?
item.description: Why nothing in the case of the arrest of a man at the British Embassy in Berlin should surprise us.

item.title: COP26: How serious is the government about climate conference?
item.description: With less than 90 days to go to Glasgow climate summit, there is uncertainty surrounding the event.

item.title: Boris Johnson: Why mining gaffe will linger after Scottish visit
item.description: Boris Johnson put his foot in it by joking that Margaret Thatcher gave the UK a "big early start" in the shift away from coal.

item.title: Riots 10 years on: The five summer nights when London burned
item.description: In August 2011 a man was shot dead by police in London, triggering the worst civil unrest in decades.

item.title: Ben Elliot: Conservative Party money man with A-list connections
item.description: Tory fundraiser and co-chairman Ben Elliot is at the centre of controversy over an elite donors club.

item.title: Indyref2: Why has the campaign for another vote gone quiet?
item.description: Boris Johnson visits Scotland with no sign an independence referendum will be soon, writes Nick Eardley.

item.title: Covid-19: Behind-the-scenes battles over amber watchlist
item.description: Cabinet divisions over international travel rules spilled out into the open this week, writes Adam Fleming.

item.title: Tragedy became Sliding Doors moment for politician
item.description: Julie James's life changed overnight when the father of her first child was killed in a car crash.

item.title: Guli Francis-Dehqani: The bishop tackling England's housing crisis
item.description: The Church of England owns a lot of land - Guli Francis-Dehqani wants to use it for the common good.

item.title: Official Secrets Act: Do government plans threaten investigative journalism?
item.description: Campaigners and reporters say planned changes to the Official Secrets Act threaten press freedoms.

item.title: Zimbabwean with football dreams to be kicked out of UK
item.description: Christopher Arundell grew up in the UK but after doing time in jail is being deported to Zimbabwe.

item.title: What happens to British ships when satellites don't work?
item.description: The Royal Navy and merchant fleet have no back-up if navigation systems are disrupted, experts warn.

item.title: Boris Johnson's police numbers claim fact-checked
item.description: A look at the prime minister's claims about crime statistics, police numbers and funding.

item.title: John Stonehouse: Bizarre tale of the MP who faked his own death
item.description: Was John Stonehouse a spy who betrayed his country? Or a naive and broken man? James Naughtie investigates.

item.title: Brexit: What's the Northern Ireland Protocol?
item.description: Urgent changes to the post-Brexit Northern Ireland Protocol have been called for by the UK government.

item.title: Cummings: Eight takeaways from his interview
item.description: The PM's former chief adviser on lockdowns, Downing Street rows, Brexit and coup discussions.

item.title: Covid rules: What's changing in Wales, Scotland, England and Northern Ireland?
item.description: Lockdown rules are changing across the UK, but some restrictions remain in place.
